block.p: From the Manhattan-centered view of the universe, Kmart has long been one of the big symbols of the world Out There, a caricature of strip mall culture at its height, or depth. Kmart, in turn, ignored Manhattan completely. Manhattan was antithesis, everything that Kmart was not, lacking everything that had made the Kmart formula work everywhere else. Now, Manhattan has become a critical element in the company's plans for a rebirth. $(Page A1.$)

As the Yankees prepared for the playoffs, at least part of the jabber among the city's jabbering baseball fans was about George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the team's principal owner, who -- unlike previous years -- has let his manager and general manager do the talking for the team. The question is: Has he mellowed? $(B1.$)

Mayor Giuliani significantly broadened his attack on the new Federal welfare law, saying that the denial of social services to legal immigrants was both morally wrong and unconstitutional. The Mayor accused Congress and President Clinton of trying to limit immigration by making the lives of immigrants miserable. $(B1.$)
Thirteen months before he seeks re-election, the Mayor is leading his potential rivals, a poll finds. $(B7.$)

After selling both their vacation homes to consolidate their lives in the city, George and Catherine Parry longed for the water sports they both love. Then, as they gazed upon the Central Park Reservoir from their Fifth Avenue apartment, the couple hit upon an idea to fill the void. Wearing full scuba gear, they are working to clear more than a century's worth of garbage from the reservoir. $(B1.$)

The Rev. William Greenlaw can't really explain it, but for about the last six weeks -- coincidentally or not the period since President Clinton signed the welfare-overhaul law -- lines have grown a lot longer at the soup kitchen he runs out of the Episcopal Church of the Holy Apostles. Even before the sweeping changes, soup kitchens and pantries were struggling to keep pace with a sharp rise in demand. NYC by Clyde Haberman. $(B1.$)

Stanley Hill, the head of the city's largest municipal union was criticized by fellow labor leaders for failing to win more concessions from Mayor Giuliani before the city expands its workfare program. $(B3.$)
Nearly three weeks after building violations forced the delay of classes at the High School for Cooperative Technical Education, the school is ready to open. $(B3.$)

Martin Dunn, the top editor of The Daily News, is leaving the paper, becoming the latest of several senior editors to depart since Mortimer B. Zuckerman bought the tabloid in 1993. No successor was named. $(B3.$)

Testifying in a civil suit, a prison guard denied allegations that they had an affair with Amy Fisher in 1993. Miss Fisher, who is serving 5 to 15 years for shooting the wife of a former boyfriend, Joey Buttafuoco, has sued to be transferred to the Federal prison system. $(B5.$)

The City Comptroller raised new questions about how the Giuliani administration awards millions of dollars in contracts, contending that mental health officials had ignored guidelines intended to prevent mismanagement and patronage. City Hall said the criticism was inaccurate. $(B6.$)
Carla Lockwood pleaded not guilty to murder charges stemming from the starvation death of her 4-year-old daughter, Nadine. $(B7.$)

Lawyers for Alex Kelly, the onetime high school wrestling star who fled to Europe when he was charged with raping two teen-age girls a decade ago, are to begin selecting a jury for a trial of one of the rape cases. Mr. Kelly faces new charges stemming from a car accident. $(B5.$)

A former Green Beret colonel who served as a mediator in the Freemen standoff in Montana was arrested on charges that he tried to kidnap a middle school student in Suffield. His son was also charged. $(B7.$)

Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Connecticut has agreed to merge with Anthem Inc., a big Midwestern insurance company that is rapidly expanding across the country, people with knowledge of the deal said. The Connecticut insurer would become part of Anthem East Inc., based in Newark, along with Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans in New Jersey and Delaware. Business Day. $(D8.$)

A retired psychiatrist and his wife, a social worker, were found stabbed to death in their home in a wealthy section of Englewood, and a man with a bloody shirt, described by investigators as their 30-year-old son, was being questioned. $(B5.$)

From the Manhattan-centered view of the universe, Kmart has long been one of the big symbols of the world Out There, a caricature of strip mall culture at its height, or depth. Kmart, in turn, ignored Manhattan completely. Manhattan was antithesis, everything that Kmart was not, lacking everything that had made the Kmart formula work everywhere else. Now, Manhattan has become a critical element in the company's plans for a rebirth. $(Page A1.$)

Steinbrenner 3d, the team's principal owner, who -- unlike previous years -- has let his manager and general manager do the talking for the team. The question is: Has he mellowed? $(B1.$)
